stream_context.summary: Kaze spends most of the stream white-boarding the design of Course 15, a new "Space Arcade" level for Return to Yoshi's Island.  He lays out high-level goals (fun, freedom, awe), debates linearity vs openness, chooses specific star concepts, settles on a hub-and-paths layout with a pinball flipper zone beneath the main platforms, and confirms technical feasibility on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 will be called “Space Arcade / Asteroid Arcade” and is conceived as a space-themed amusement zone built around a central rocket-ship landmark.
development_findings.quote: We should have the rocket ship you spawn around, and from there the main stuff branches out.

development_findings.summary: Primary design goals: (1) fun & freedom, (2) player always knows the objective (“certainty of goals”), (3) evoke awe through lights/visuals, (4) low-gravity platforming.
development_findings.quote: Most important order of business: do not ever have the player question what to do… Certainty of goals, freedom in how to achieve those goals movement-wise.

development_findings.summary: Macro layout: three main paths radiate from the rocket hub; below them is a flipper-pinball floor that doubles as the red-coin challenge and a trampoline back to the main area; teleporters/black holes lead to distant sub-areas like the Moon.
development_findings.quote: If we put the flipper star and all the flipper platforms entirely below the main course and shoot you up, that would connect everything so much… I think I like that a lot.

development_findings.summary: Six planned stars: 1) Pinball red-coins on flipper field, 2) Pac-Man–style Chain-Chomp maze arcade cabinet, 3) Tetris falling-blocks survival cabinet, 4) Skateball (cannon launch to score), 5) Hot-Rope Jump minigame, 6) 8-bit pipe secret area. Whack-a-Mole & rhythm-game ideas were discarded.

Technical features already working: global low-gravity zones; planetary gravity code (from Raphael Raven boss) exists but will not be used here; engine holds a solid 60 FPS on real N64 even with all enhancements.
development_findings.quote: I'd say this level runs pretty well on N64 so far—solid 60 FPS. That's just how powerful the engine is.

development_findings.summary: New enemy concepts: space variants of Shy Guys (tall, lanky, possible spin attack) and Skeeters recolored for alien vibe; mechanical hazards will dominate the level.
Kaze references Super Mario Galaxy’s structure (linear stretches punctuated by open sections) as the main influence for solving the linear-vs-open dilemma.
development_findings.quote: This is the level that feels the least linear of all of Galaxy—they achieve this by having open sections in between.

development_findings.summary: The course will probably be the physically largest in the game due to required linear stretches between set-pieces.

Demo (Course 1) is feature-complete and targeted for release shortly after Christmas to dodge Nintendo legal attention; full engine will be open-sourced only after the game ships to avoid leaking content.
development_findings.quote: If I open-source it right now I'd leak my entire game… It will be open source once it’s finished.

context_findings.summary: Kaze’s design philosophy emphasises ‘edging’—showing players tantalising sights from afar to build anticipation before access is granted.
context_findings.quote: Edging the player is important—you can’t put something out there and let them get it immediately.

context_findings.summary: He experiences visible frustration with repeated chat requests for Roblox, reaffirming focus on his own projects.
Thinks releasing hacks around Christmas increases risk of Nintendo takedowns, so he plans post-holiday drops.
context_findings.quote: If you release stuff around Christmas, Nintendo gets very angry.

context_findings.summary: Views on programming: learnt MIPS assembly first, then C; believes C is straightforward once assembly is known.
context_findings.quote: My first week of programming C in my entire life I made Mario 64 split-screen multiplayer on the N64.

biobak.summary: Suggested an 8-bit pipe placement idea for the Yoshi-coin area, which Kaze considers but may relocate.

key_stories.title: The Flipper Floor Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: While struggling to balance openness with goal clarity, Kaze realises he can place the red-coin pinball flipper field beneath the main platforms.  The flippers act both as a star challenge and as trampolines that shoot Mario back into the central paths, unifying movement and exploration.
key_stories.challenge: Make the level feel non-linear yet keep goals obvious.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed Galaxy-style open sections, considered teleporters; then sketched a vertical stack where flippers sit below the hub.
key_stories.outcome: Adopted the ‘under-floor pinball’ concept as a core mechanic, connecting paths and providing the red-coin star.
key_stories.key_quote: If we put the flipper platforms entirely below the main course and shoot you up… that would connect everything so much.

key_stories.title: Selecting Arcade Stars
key_stories.summary: Kaze sifts through arcade and Mario Party minigame ideas, rejecting those that don’t translate to platforming, before settling on Pac-Man and Tetris as workable, fun cabinet challenges.
key_stories.challenge: Find two arcade-style stars that are fun with Mario’s movement and avoid dull memory or gambling mechanics.
key_stories.process: Evaluated whack-a-mole, rhythm games, shell games; browsed Mario Party minigames; weighed camera and programming complexity.
key_stories.outcome: Commits to a Chain-Chomp Pac-Man maze and a falling-blocks Tetris survival room.
key_stories.key_quote: Pac-Man with Chain Chomps kind of would go hard—let’s do that.

key_stories.title: Delaying the Demo for Legal Safety
key_stories.summary: The first-world demo is ready, but Kaze plans to release it only after the Christmas season to reduce the odds of a Nintendo takedown.
key_stories.challenge: Nintendo is historically aggressive with fan projects, especially during holidays.
key_stories.process: Assesses timing; decides to upload on his secondary ‘KazeClips’ channel post-holiday.
key_stories.outcome: Demo release window moved to early January; legal risk mitigated.
key_stories.key_quote: I will release it shortly after Christmas, because if you release stuff around Christmas, Nintendo gets very angry.

open_questions.context: Kaze says low-gravity zones are planned and planetary gravity already exists from another boss but won’t be used here.
questions: How exactly will low-gravity zones be delineated within Course 15?
Why was planetary gravity deemed unsuitable for this level?
Could planetary gravity re-appear elsewhere in the hack?

open_questions.topic: Space Shy Guy & Skeeter enemy designs
open_questions.context: He proposes lanky space Shy Guys and recolored Skeeters but hasn’t finalised behaviour or visuals.
questions: What final visual style and attacks did you settle on for the space Shy Guys?
Will Biobak or Zeina handle the modeling/animation, and how do you brief them?
How do these enemies complement the mechanical hazards already planned?

open_questions.context: Pac-Man and Tetris concepts chosen, but camera, controls, and star win conditions are still speculative.
questions: What camera solution will you use inside the Pac-Man maze to avoid player disorientation?
Will the Tetris cabinet include line clears or just falling hazards?
How will you convey arcade rules without text (since the level has ‘purely no text’)?

open_questions.context: Little mention of Badub’s music or Zeina’s animation for this level.
questions: Is Badub composing a unique ‘space arcade’ track, and what mood are you aiming for?
What specific asset requests will Zeina animate (e.g., flipper pieces, lanky Shy Guy spins)?
How does the hand-off pipeline work for a level of this scope?

open_questions.context: Kaze promises to open-source the engine post-release.
questions: What license will you choose for the open-source release?
Do you foresee community contributions shaping post-launch updates?
How will you separate proprietary assets from code when releasing?
